executive_summary: Lincoln USD adopted sweeping reforms: Computer Science and AI Literacy added as core/elective subjects, 1:1 Chromebook program launched, class sizes reduced to 25, professional development doubled to 40 hours with mandatory tech training, per-pupil spending increased 25%, and special education shifted to full inclusion model.

what_changed.change: Computer Science added as core subject and AI Literacy as elective; 1:1 Chromebook program replaces computer labs for grades 3-12
Class size maximum reduced from 30 to 25 students per classroom
Professional development doubled from 20 to 40 hours annually with 10 hours mandatory tech/AI training
Per-pupil spending increased from $9,200 to $11,500; technology budget 5x increase to $750,000
Special education shifted from pull-out to full inclusion model with push-in services; IEP reviews now semi-annual
Comprehensive anti-bullying and cyberbullying policy including social media conduct; mental health screening for grades 6-12
Cell phone policy strengthened to full-day collection; lockdown drills increased to monthly; threat assessment teams established

deadlines.item: 1:1 Chromebook deployment for all grades 3-12 before fall semester
All teachers complete 10-hour AI/technology training module
Mental health screening program operational for grades 6-12
Full inclusion model implemented for all IEP students

action_checklist.action: Procure and deploy Chromebooks for 1:1 program — estimated 3,000+ devices needed
Hire additional teachers to meet new 1:25 staff ratio and reduced class sizes
Develop and schedule 40-hour professional development curriculum with tech component
Establish threat assessment teams at each school site
Transition special education from pull-out to push-in model with staff retraining
Implement digital citizenship curriculum across all grade levels

risk_flags.flag: Significant budget pressure from simultaneous reforms
risk_flags.why: Per-pupil increase of $2,300, 5x technology budget, $200K mental health, $5K STEM bonuses — total new spending may exceed $3M annually.

risk_flags.flag: Teacher shortage risk from reduced class sizes
risk_flags.why: Reducing max class size from 30 to 25 requires ~20% more classrooms and teachers. Current hiring market may not support rapid staffing.
Shifting from pull-out to push-in services requires retraining all special education staff and general education teachers simultaneously.
